reviewText: The Four-Faced Liar is a trendy gay-friendly bar in a part of New York City which doesn't look like New York City in the movies. This is the place where Molly meets Trip, her colleague from her studies in 19th century literature. Molly comes to the bar with her boyfriend Greg who has just arrived in NYC, Trip brings his lesbian flat-mate Bridget, as we soon learn he has also a girl-friend, ballet-dancer Chloe. They are all in their early twenties but the film doesn't offer much information on what they do apart from meeting friends and sharing drinks.As it turns out Bridget and Molly share keen interest in 19th century novel - Wuthering Heights is their apparent favourite - and they hit it off immediately. The story line concentrates on the two girls - Molly learns to accept the fact that she is a lesbian, Bridget changes from a woman-eating out-and-proud lesbian into a possible girl-friend material. Neither change comes easy but fortunately both girls realise on time what they are about to lose if they stick to their former selves - Molly marrying Greg (who is sadly cast aside and learns rather late what is going on behind his back) and Bridget devouring more and more women. The other story line - Trip losing and winning back (and losing again) Chloe is far less prominent although offers some more laughs.There are some pros and cons, as usual with GLBT productions - pros are decent screenplay and acting, a major con for me was the quality of sound. Maybe it's just me but I found it quite difficult to follow dialogues which took place in the bar.
summary: Romantic comedy with a bit of twist

reviewText: Molly (Emily Peck) loves New York and everything about it, her boyfriend Greg (Daniel Carlisle) has just moved to the city to be with her. One night at a local pub Four-Faced Liar, they meet friends Trip (Todd Kubrak), his girlfriend Chloe (Liz Osborn) and his flat mate Bridget (Marja Lewis Ryan). While Trip and Greg bond over sports, Molly and Bridget discover a mutual love of literature.When Molly discovers that Bridget is a lesbian, she becomes even more intrigued. After a big fight with Greg, the natural place to go seems to be Bridget's place. Over long conversations and sharing a bed (platonically of course), Molly falls in love with Bridget. In the end, she must choose between a dull life with Greg or a passionate, but possibly tumultuous life with Bridget.The Four-Faced Liar is a romantic comedy/drama by director Jacob Chase that looks at life, choices and relationships, which are not always easy or straightforward.Emily Peck aptly portrays Molly, a woman whose life lacks the passion she so desires and the disorientation she feels when she suddenly realizes that she is in love with another woman.Chris AldersonAuthor of the 2013 Lesbian Film Guide

Title: N/A

reviewText: Original and (slightly) daring comedy-drama about a group of twenty-somethings who are making their life up in the West Village.  Trouble is that of the main characters only one, Marja Lewis Ryan, is even remotely likeable.  Ryan, who also wrote the screenplay, is an outspoken lesbian who is living with a male friend, Trip (Todd Kubrak).  Trip, oddly, personifies all that any woman, but perhaps especially a lesbian, would seem to detest in men.  He is wholly a cad and scoundrel.  These two and their friends are trying to figure out who they are and how they might relate to others.  Unfortunately, none of them are very appealing.  The acting is pretty good, the writing isn't bad.  It's worth the time to watch for its originality and as a slice of life that must strike someone as real.  I, fortunately, don't know any of these people, but one has to champion such independent efforts in an age that seems to value mindless movies above all.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film is not a good representative of LGBT New York. NYC is very diverse. This film is not. I would have liked this film a lot better if I felt it was realistic. New York is nearly 70% ethnic, of very diverse backgrounds. This film is not diverse at all. Even the extras are not ethnic. It's too bad that filmmakers don't pay attention to their demographics, or choose to deny the reality. Part of the experience from film is to feel it's realistic and this one failed miserably.
summary: Not a good representation of LGBT NY
